731153f-a.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Columbus Day.
731153f-a.text:
Military Parade upon the occasion of Columbus Day, October 12th., 1892.
A Connecticut Inf. Regiment is shown making a left column turn from Union
Square East, into 17th., Street.
October 12, 1892.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
731153f-a.folder: 17th Street and Union Square, Manhattan, N.Y.

723623f-a.title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).
723623f-a.text:
The new Tamummany Hall, Union Square East at the S.E. corner of
17th Streot, newly erected on the site of the old Westmoreland
Apartments (originally Hotel), which occupied the site from about
1877 to 1928. The bank is about to move into the ground floor. In
the background may be seen the tower of the nen Consolidated Gas and
New Yorl Edison Building, recently completed on 14th Street on the
site of the old Tammony Hall and the Academy of Musio.
The Society of St. Tammany, or Colunbian Ordor, was founded in
Philadelphia and spread through Hew England, before a New York City
chapter was established in 1789. It was originally a benevolent
organization, and first identified itself with politics in the
presidential campaign of 1800, when, under the leadership of Vice-
Presential candidate Aaron Burr, it supported the Jefferson-Surr
ticket. The first Tammany Hall, built in 1801, stood on Frankfort
and Nassau Streets. On July 4, 1868, the second Hall on 14th Street
was opened with the Democratic National Convention of that year. In
1928 it moved into the present building.
The Tammany Hall General Committee, with which it is practically
identical in membership, has for a long time bcen in control of the
Democrctic Party in New York County, at times almost to the point of
complete identification with it. This picture, for instance, is taken
near the height of Mayor James J. .alker's popularity, the spring
preceding his re-election. Tammany Hall is not only identified with
the Party in Manhattan, but is working harmoniously with the leaders
of the other four boroughs.
May, 1929.

723624f-a.title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).
723624f-a.text:
Tammany Hall, Union Square East at S.E. corner of 17th Street,
the ground floor occupied by a branch of the Manufacturers
Trust Company. The new Tammany Hall is four years old, as
pictured here. At the time it was built, the store of 42
UUnion Square, adjoining, was occupied by Flaxman Woolen,
Incorporated.
March 25, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, Election Day of that year, when, for the first time in
twenty years, the Tammany candidates for Mayor, Comptroller,
and Aldermanic President were all defeated. But the Borough
President and four candidates for County Offices, whose names
follow the first three, were elected.
The building in the background, with the ''Hyman -- Human -- '' sig
is not shown in this view because of the angle of the camera.
November 7, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCIIONS.

723625f-a.title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).
723625f-a.text:
Union Square East (Fourth Avenue), at the S. E. corner
of East 17th Street (left), showing the building housing
the Columbian Order, better known as Tammany Hall.
1940
George D. Chinn

723626f-c.title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 17th Street (East).
723626f-c.text:
Union Square East (normally 4th Avenue) at E. 17th
Street as photographed northeastward from variods points.
No. 1 is from the diagonal far corner of the Square, at
Broadway and 14th Street; No. 2 from atop an office struc-
ture on the same street and No. 3 from inside the Park.
Occupying the various corners at this point are, the
Everett Building, the Guardian Life Insurance Co. Build-
ing and Tammany Hall. Incidentally, Fourth Avenue, offi-
cially starts there and that portion bordering the Square
is identified by same.
The Lincoln statue appears in the earlier view. This
is at the Broadway point, popularly known as ''Death Curve.''
This arose from the danger to pedestrians from the speed-
ing Broadway streetcars on their turn into 14th Street
from Union Square West.
View 11 February 12, 1928 Neg N. 221
View 2: August 4, 1930 Neg A. 1i
View 3: February 24, 1933
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODU:TIONS
